description.p: Apearing poor and beaten down, a young human girl tugs at an elder man’s coat, begging for some coin. The man agrees, and before he knows it, he awakes to find himself lost within the woods.
Wielding the spirits of her forefathers, a bright-eyed gnome sacrifices the power of her blood to heal her allies and keep them alive in their fight against a powerful lich lord.
Seething with anger, a dwarf unleashes his rage, causing a mass frenzy wherein he feasts on the screams of terror as bodies fall to the ground.

Standing completely still in a fervent marketplace while citizens run for their lives, a brutish half-orc looks content as his eyes gaze upon the current decimation he had seen previously in his worst nightmares. "This day will be my last" he thinks to himself, and releases a powerful spell to sheild others from the wrath of the apocalypse as he himself is swept up and destroyed by it.

Both feared and respected, Soothsayers hold unique abilities whether gifted or trained, to peer past the current situation and discover a new strategy. They learn to use this ability to either warn locals or save themselves, getting out while the going’s good, so to say.
Some soothsayers are fully engulfed within this power over time, and take a devious perogative to bend the future to their liking.

As you create your Soothsayer character, consider how or why you acquired your abilities. Did witnessing the death of a loved one push you along the track for revenge at any cost? Were you part of a crime syndicate that teaches situational magics? or have you always had the ability to sense what is unknown to others due to a magical bloodline? Perhaps you served a fiendish master and wish to outsmart them out of fear for your safety.

At 2nd level, Soothsayers pick their altered path, a subclass that sticks them into numerous tests of deciscion-making and puzzle-solving. The life of a Soothsayer is wrought with mental hardships and your character needs a solid reason to pick this path of dodging mental instability and visions of an altered world.

You can make a soothsayer quickly by following these suggestions. First, make Intelligence your highest ability score, followed by Dexterity (Some Soothsayers who seek a more direct approach may swap the order of these scores.) Second, choose the Haunted One background.
As a soothsayer, you gain the following class features.

ul.li: Hit Points at 1st Level: 8 + your Constitution modifier
Hit Points at Higher Levels: 1d8 (or 5) + your Constitution modifier per soothsayer level after 1st
Tools: Gaming Set, one type of Artisan’s Tools
Skills: Choose two from Acrobatics, Arcana, History, Insight, Investigation, Perception, Religion and Survival

description.p: You start with the following equipment, in addition to the equipment granted by your background:

ul.li: (a) Set of Hide Armor or (b) any simple weapon
(a) Hand Crossbow and 20 bolts or (b) any simple ranged weapon
Leather armor, an arcane focus, one type of artisan’s tools, and (a) priest’s pack or (b) scholar’s pack

description.p: You must have an Intelligence score of 14 or higher in order to multiclass in or out of this class.

setters.set: A mystic that can peer past the current situation and see a new strategy.

description.p: At 1st level, choose two of your skill proficiencies, or one of your skill proficiencies and your proficiency with Artisan’s tools. Your proficiency bonus is doubled for any ability check you make that uses either of the chosen proficiencies.
At 9th level, you can choose two more of your proficiencies (in skills or with artisan’s tools) to gain this benefit.
At 2nd level, you have been cursed with a hunger for what lies beyond. This hunger is represented by Sanity Points, which allow you to unlock a toolbox of unique effects.

You have 2 sanity points, and you gain more as you reach higher levels, as shown in the Sanity Points column of the Soothsayer table. You can never have more sanity points than what is shown on the table. You regain all spent spent sanity points after finishing a short or long rest.

You have acquired specialized powers of a supernatural origin that allow you to sacrifice pieces of your soul and mind to peer beyond the thin veil of reality. However you gained these powers, they are what fuels your spellcasting. See the general rules of spellcasting in the 5th edition Player’s Handbook and page 5 of this document for the soothsayer spell list.

You can use your sanity points to cast spells in place of regular spell slots by expending a number equal to the spell’s level. Spells cast this way can be cast either as an action, bonus action, or reaction (regardless of the spell’s casting time). Expending sanity points in this way casts the spell in that moment, and any ritual spells cast using sanity points are cast as a bonus action.

If you have both the Spellcasting class feature and the Mental Crux class feature from the soothsayer class, you can use sanity points to cast spells you know or have prepared from classes with the Spellcasting class feature, and you can use the spell slots you gain from the Spellcasting class feature to cast soothsayer spells you know.

When a soothsayer runs out of sanity points, they roll a d10 and suffer an effect according to the temporary insanity table. This effect lasts until the soothsayer regains at least 1 sanity point from either meditating for 10 minutes, or by finishing a short or long rest.
A soothsayer can spend 10 minutes readjusting themselves to the material plane to regain 1 sanity point.
description.h5: SPELLS KNOWN OF 1ST LEVEL AND HIGHER
description.p: You know two 1st level spells of your choice from the soothsayer spell list.

The Spells Known column of the Soothsayer table shows when you learn more soothsayer spells of your choice. Each of those spells must be of a level no higher than what’s shown in the table’s Slot Level column for your level. When you reach 9th level, for example, you can learn a new soothsayer spell, which can be 1st, 2nd, or 3rd level.

Intelligence is your spellcasting ability for your soothsayer spells, so you use your Intelligence whenever a spell refers to your spellcasting ability. In addition, you use your Intelligence modifier when setting the saving throw DC for a soothsayer spell you cast and when making an attack roll with one.

center.p: Spell save DC = 8 + your proficiency bonus + your Intelligence modifier
Spell attack modifier = your proficiency bonus + your Intelligence modifier

tr.td: You can’t speak or prepare vocal components of spells
You have disadvantage on sleight of hand checks and can’t prepare somatic components of spells
Melee attacks you make have disadvatage

sheet.description: You can spend sanity points to cast spells by spending 1 sanity point per level of the spell. Spells cast this way can be cast either as an action, bonus action, or reaction (regardless of the spell’s casting time). Expending sanity points in this way casts the spell in that moment, and any ritual spells cast using sanity points are cast as a bonus action. If you drop to 0 sanity points, you suffer one of the effects on the Temporary Insanity table.

description.p: At 2nd level, you divulge into the nature of your extrasensory abilities and the strange, twisted destiny you have set out to claim in the form of an altered path. The available altered paths are Path of the Astral Soul, Path of the Ancient Order, Path of the Fanatic, or Path of the Fateweaver. Each gives you features at 2nd level and again at 6th, 10th, 14th, and 18th level.
The driving force behind a soothsayer’s adventures is their altered path. A vision or series of visions that shown them a seperate point in time or space.

Some soothsayers are destined to have these visions, while others deliberately seek answers to, or an escape from the problems of their world, leading them to stumble upon something they shouldn’t have.
Beginning at 3rd level, you gain the ability to pull others into your visions of an altered world.
Once per long rest, you can touch a willing humanoid and share a vision of what is yet to come. Both you and the chosen creature gain advantage on their next attack, skill check, or saving throw.
At 7th level, you may use this ability a number of times equal to your Intelligence modifier (Minimum 2).

sheet.description: You can touch a willing humanoid and share a vision of what is yet to come. Both you and the chosen creature gain advantage on their next attack, skill check, or saving throw.

description.p: When you reach 4th level, and again at 8th, 12th, 16th, and 19th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can’t increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
Using the optional feats rule, you can forgo taking this feature to take a feat of your choice instead.
Beginning at 5th level, you can attack twice, instead of once, whenever you take the Attack action on your turn.

sheet.description: You can attack twice, instead of once, whenever you take the Attack action on your turn.

description.p: Beginning at 11th level, and again at 13th, 15th, 17th level, you gain an additional reaction during combat which you can use to cast spells, make opportunity attacks, or trigger a readied action.

sheet.description: You have {{extra-reaction:count}} reactions per turn.

description.p: At 20th level, After dipping in and out of what is yet to come of this world, you have gained a mastery over the sands of time themselves. You no longer suffer the effects of temporary insanity, and can’t be charmed or frightened.

sheet.description: You no longer suffer the effects of temporary insanity, and can’t be charmed or frightened.

description.p: Your visions show scenes of a world from long ago. Perhaps you see an empire lost to time, or maybe the very lives of your ancestors or past selves. No matter the substance of these visions, they have instilled within you the need to not let the lives of those before you to disappear from history again.

Starting at 2nd level when you choose this path, you gain the ability to summon the spirit of an ancient warrior to fight by your side for 1 minute, or until you lose concentration. Once per long rest, you can use a bonus action to summon a spectral warrior with ability scores equal to your own, a base AC of 13, hit points equal to 1d12 + your soothsayer level, and 30 feet of movement speed. The spectral warrior also has a ghastly blade which deals magical piercing or slashing damage equal to 1d6 + your soothsayer level.
The spectral warrior can only be summoned in an unoccupied space within 30 feet of you, and can’t move further than 120 feet away from you. You and the spirit warrior share the same turn.

sheet.description: You can summon the spirit of an ancient warrior to an unoccupied space within 30 feet of you. The warrior as a base AC of 13, 1d12 + {{level:soothsayer}} hit points, and 30 feet movement speed. The warrior can attack with a ghastly blade for 1d6 + {{level:soothsayer}} slashing or piercing damage. The spectral warrior has ability scores identical to yours and shares the same turn.

description.p: Beginning at 6th level, you can use a reaction and spend 3 sanity points to switch places with your spectral warrior when either you or the spectral warrior is attacked.

sheet.description: You can switch places with your spectral warrior when either you or your spectral warrior is attacked.

description.p: Starting at 10th level, your spectral warriors have their own turn and you roll initiative for each of them when summoning one or more.

sheet.description: Your spectral warriors have their own turn and you roll initiative for each of them when summoning one or more.

description.p: Starting at 14th level, whenever you have a spectral warrior summoned, you have advantage on all melee attacks.

sheet.description: Whenever you have a spectral warrior summoned, you have advantage on all melee attacks.

description.p: At 18th level, you have mastered the act of conjuring spirits to aid you in the heat of battle. Once per long rest, you can use a bonus action to summon 5 spectral warriors.
The spectral warriors can only be summoned in an unoccupied space within 30 feet of you, and can’t move further than 120 feet away from you.

sheet.description: You can summon 5 spectral warriors. The spectral warriors can only be summoned in an unoccupied space within 30 feet of you, and can’t move further than 120 feet away from you.

description.p: You have sought out beings from the far realms, ageless cosmic horrors which have torn your mind and soul to scraps. Your reason for finding them doesn’t matter anymore, what does matter is how you will use the powers you now hold as a champion of the great old ones.

Starting at 2nd level when you choose this path, you gain the power to domineer your will over another creature. You can touch an unwilling creature, forcing it to make a Wisdom saving throw against your soothsayer spell save DC. If the creature fails, you can spend any number of sanity points and beguile it for that many turns, during which you can communicate with it telepathically. This effect ends if you harm the creature in any way, fall unconscious, run out of sanity points, or target another creature with this ability. Creatures immune to being charmed or frightened automatically pass the saving throw.

sheet.description: You can touch an unwilling creature, forcing it to make a Wisdom saving throw against your soothsayer spell save DC. If the creature fails, you can spend any number of sanity points and beguile it for that many turns, during which you can communicate with it telepathically. This effect ends if you harm the creature in any way, fall unconscious, run out of sanity points, or target another creature with this ability. Creatures immune to being charmed or frightened automatically pass the saving throw.

description.p: At 6th level, you learn any two eldritch invocations that you meet the requirements for.
Beginning at 10th level, you can spend 3 sanity points to repeat the last spell cast.

sheet.description: You can spend 3 sanity points to repeat the last spell cast.

description.p: At 14th level, you can call upon a twisted horror of the far realms for aid. As an action, you open a portal at a point you can see within 30 feet of you and choose one of the following effects.

ul.li: Transport. You and up to 5 willing creatures of your choice that you can see are grasped by tentacles that emerge from the portal. A second portal opens at a point that you can see, depositing you and your chosen allies there.

Fury. The tentacles slam onto your foes. Pick up to 5 creatures that you can see within 30 feet of the portal. Those creatures must make Dexterity saving throws against your soothsayer spell save DC. Creatures that fail their saving throw take 10d6 bludgeoning damage and are restrained for 1 minute. Those that succeed take half the bludgeoning damage and are not restrained. On its turn, a restrained creature can use its action to attempt a DC 15 Strength (Athletics) or Dexterity (Acrobatics) check to end the restrained condition.

description.p: Once you use this ability, you cannot use it again until you complete a long rest.

sheet.description: You open a portal at a point you can see within 30 feet of you and choose one of the following effects. Transport up to 5 willing creatures or attack up to 5 creatures. Creatures attacked must make a Dexterity saving throw (save DC {{spellcasting:dc}}) or take 10d6 bludgeoning damage and be restrained (DC 15 to escape) for 1 minute, half damage on a success.

description.p: At 18th level, Thralls you create are controlled by you indefinetly, and at the beginning of your turn you can siphon 2d6 hit points from your thrall.

sheet.description: Thralls you create are controlled by you indefinetly, and at the beginning of your turn you can siphon 2d6 hit points from your thrall.

description.p: Some soothsayers have seen an apocalyptic event, and have become consumed by the need to force fate towards this eventual future. Many soothsayers that choose this path also believe that they must be the one to shepherd the end times.
Starting at 2nd level when you choose this path, you can spend 1 sanity point as a bonus action to enter a rage.
While raging, you gain the following benefits if you aren’t wearing heavy armor:

ul.li: You have advantage on Dexterity checks and Dexterity saving throws.
When you make a melee weapon attack using Dexterity, you gain a bonus to the damage roll equal to your soothsayer level.
You have resistance to bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing damage. If you are able to cast spells, you can’t cast them or concentrate on them while raging.

description.p: Your rage lasts for 1 minute. It ends early if you are knocked unconscious or if your turn ends and you haven’t attacked a hostile creature since your last turn or taken damage since then. You can also end your rage on your turn as a bonus action.

sheet.description: You can enter a rage. While raging and not wearing heavy armor, you have advantage on Dexterity checks and saving throws. When making a melee attack using Dexterity, you can add {{level:soothsayer}} damage. You have resistance to bludgeoning, piercing and slashing damage. You can’t cast or concentrate on spells while raging.

description.p: Beginning at 6th level, you can show other creatures visions of their death. Whenever you make a successful grapple check against a creature, you can expend any number of sanity points, dealing 1d6 psychic damage for each sanity point spent.

sheet.description: Whenever you make a successful grapple check against a creature, you can expend any number of sanity points, dealing 1d6 psychic damage for each sanity point spent.

description.p: Beginning at 10th level, you can attack up to three times whenever you take the Attack action on your turn.

sheet.description: You can attack up to three times whenever you take the Attack action on your turn.

description.p: Beginning at 14th level, whenever you kill a creature, you gain 20 temporary hit points.

sheet.description: Whenever you kill a creature, you gain 20 temporary hit points.

description.p: At 18th level, you can force all willing creatures within 60 feet of you to be flung into a maniacal rage for 1 minute.

sheet.description: You can force all willing creatures within 60 feet of you to be flung into a maniacal rage for 1 minute.

description.p: Your visions have manifested themselves into endless repetitions of others’ deaths. You have thus sworn to find a way to protect others from their own violent downfalls to the point of disregarding your own mortality.
Starting at 2nd level, you can use a reaction to redirect an attack against an ally towards you.

sheet.description: You can use a reaction to redirect an attack against an ally towards you.

description.p: At 6th level, you become resistant to all damage dealt by outside sources.

sheet.description: You become resistant to all damage dealt by outside sources.

description.p: Beginning at 10th level, you can expend any number of sanity points as a bonus action and increase another willing creature’s AC by 1 for each sanity point spent.

sheet.description: You can expend any number of sanity points as a bonus action and increase another willing creature’s AC by 1 for each sanity point spent.

description.p: At 14th level, you gain the ability to cast spells using your blood, spending hit points equal to 2x a spell’s level. Spells cast this way require no material components.

sheet.description: You can cast spells using your blood, spending hit points equal to 2x a spell’s level. Spells cast this way require no material components.

description.p: Beginning at 18th level, you can use a bonus action to shield any number of willing creatures from harm, redirecting all attacks made against your allies to you for 1 minute to you.

sheet.description: You can use a bonus action to shield any number of willing creatures from harm, redirecting all attacks made against your allies to you for 1 minute to you.

description.p: Add 20 to the next roll of one willing creature within range that you can see.
At Higher Levels. When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 2nd level or higher, choose one more creature for each slot level above 1st.
Target creature moves its maximum movement speed in one direction that you designate, and takes 2d6 psychic damage.
At Higher Levels. When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 3rd level or higher, the damage increases by 1d6 for each slot level above 2nd.

You point your finger, and the creature that damaged you is momentarily engulfed by visions of its worst fear. The creature must make an Intelligence saving throw. It takes 4d10 psychic damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful save.
You attempt to interrupt and steal a spell as its being cast. Make an ability check using your spellcasting ability. The DC is equal to 10 + the spell’s level.

You attempt to show one creature within range its death. The target must succeed on a Charisma saving throw or it is pullled forward in time to the point of its demise. The target is then immediately pulled back to reality, suffering 6d8 psychic damage on a failed save, or have as much on a passed one.
For the duration, you can read the thoughts of all creatures within range.

You create a small poppet from which you can control another creature’s movements. damaging the poppet in any way will cause the target to take 4d8 damage of a type associated with the act. For example, if you stomped on the poppet, its target would take 4d8 magical bludgeoning damage.

setters.set: a doll or similar figure worth at least 1gp, a lock of the target’s hair

description.p: You attempt to send one creature that you can see within range to its death. The target must succeed on a Charisma saving throw or it is pullled forward in time to the point of its demise. The target remains there until the spell ends, at which point the target reappears in the space it left or in the nearest unoccupied space if that space is occupied. If the spell ends before 1 minute has passed, the target reappears in the space it left or in the nearest unoccupied space if that space is occupied. Otherwise, the target doesn’t return.
